clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of a Secure Message Reminder on Hypertension Follow-up at an Integrated Health Care System
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of a Secure Message Reminder on Hypertension Follow-up at an Integrated Health Care Delivery System

brief_summary.textblock: This study will assess whether adding a secure message reminder to routine care improves the percentage of patients who complete a follow-up appointment with a new, documented blood pressure reading.

detailed_description.textblock: Hypertension is one of the leading risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Optimizing blood pressure management can help prevent adverse cardiovascular outcomes. The National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) defines blood pressure control as less than 140/90 mmHg. Per this definition, less than half of Americans with hypertension are considered controlled. Literature has been published describing several ways of improving blood pressure management, but results have been variable.

primary_outcome.measure: Appointment with new blood pressure reading
primary_outcome.description: Percentage of patients who complete an appointment with a new documented blood pressure reading within six weeks after distributing the secure message reminder

secondary_outcome.measure: New appointment with new blood pressure reading
Existing appointment kept with new blood pressure reading

arm_group.description: Will receive a secure message reminder asking subjects to schedule an appointment with their provider or make a nurse visit to follow-up on their blood pressure

intervention.description: Single secure message reminder asking subjects to schedule an appointment with their provider or make a nurse visit to follow-up on their blood pressure

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Member of Kaiser Permanente Georgia Pharmacy Cardiac Risk Service (PCRS)
- 18-75 years of age
- Enrolled in http://kp.org
- Most recent documented blood pressure is greater than or equal to 140/90 mmHg
Exclusion Criteria:
- Most recent documented blood pressure is greater than or equal to 180/110 mmHg

reference.citation: Glynn LG, Murphy AW, Smith SM, Schroeder K, Fahey T. Interventions used to improve control of blood pressure in patients with hypertension. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2010 Mar 17;(3):CD005182. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD005182.pub4. Review.
